The Iranian government has entered a state of alert due to the deployment of U.S. military assets, including the USS Abraham Lincoln carrier strike group, to the Middle East, raising fears of a potential military attack backed by Israel. Analysts note that U.S. forces are now within operational range to strike Iranian territory, despite not yet being fully positioned. The Pentagon has conducted military exercises in the region to demonstrate combat air power mobilization and sustainment capabilities. This move comes amid internal instability in Iran, marked by violent crackdowns on ongoing protests. Western officials believe the U.S., in coordination with Israel, has sufficient firepower to launch a large-scale offensive aimed at weakening or toppling the Iranian regime. However, experts caution that such an attack may not reignite popular uprisings, as many Iranian critics of the clerical regime oppose foreign-imposed regime change. The Iranian stock market recorded its largest single-day drop in history, and inflation reached 60% in the last month, worsening public discontent. Iran’s Foreign Ministry spokesperson Esmail Baghaei denied any ongoing dialogue with Washington, dismissing claims that U.S. envoy Steve Witkoff was in contact with Foreign Minister Abbas Araghchi. Iran’s judiciary chief, Gholam-Hossein Mohseni-Ejei, publicly urged against returning to negotiations with the U.S. President Donald Trump previously delayed an offensive due to lack of a clear plan to remove Supreme Leader Ali Khamenei and insufficient guarantees for Israel’s security.
